deliberation: Checked for metaphors (e.g., gate as something else), idioms, or symbolic directions. The verse simply narrates movement to a literal gate facing east; no non-literal use of key terms is evident.

Looked at כבוד as possible metonymy and noted the explicit simile with כְקוֹל. Also considered whether the earth being lit is hyperbolic; in Ezekiel's theophanies it functions as literal visionary brightness, so I did not treat it as figurative. Two clear figurative expressions remain.

instances.english_text: with a roar like the roar of mighty waters
target: the sound of the God of Israel’s approach
ground: overwhelming volume and awe‑inspiring power
auditory intensity and majesty
shared sensory qualities
instances.explanation: The approach of God’s glory is compared explicitly to the sound of many waters to convey its power and overwhelming loudness.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּבוֹד אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל בָּא מִדֶּרֶךְ הַקָּדִים
instances.english_text: the Presence (glory) of the God of Israel was coming from the east
target: the God of Israel in his manifested presence
ground: the visible/weighty manifestation stands for the personal presence of God
attribute representing its bearer
conceptual association
instances.explanation: כָּבוֹד (‘glory’) here does not just mean an abstract quality but stands metonymically for God’s manifested presence, almost functioning as a personal agent approaching from the east.

deliberation: The repeated כְמַרְאֵה merely compares this vision with earlier visions; that is a literal comparison of similar experiences, not a figurative mapping to a different domain. However, “I fell on my face” is a stereotyped formula for prostration in awe; while he can literally fall, the phrase functions idiomatically for a worship posture.

ground: complete submission and awe expressed through being down on one’s face
physical lowliness signifying humility and fear
body posture symbolizing inner attitude
instances.explanation: In biblical narrative, “falling on one’s face” is a conventional idiom for total prostration in awe or worship, highlighting attitude more than the mechanics of literally tripping and hitting the ground.

deliberation: Again considered whether ‘glory’ is abstract or a metonym for God’s presence. Within Ezekiel’s visions, כבוד יהוה functions as a quasi‑personal, mobile presence; that is a standard metonymic/anthropomorphic usage.

instances.english_text: The Presence (glory) of GOD entered the temple
target: YHWH himself in his indwelling presence
vehicle: ‘glory’ (כָּבוֹד) as something that can move and enter
ground: the visible, weighty radiance stands for God’s personal entry
attribute treated as an acting agent
representation of the unseen by a seen form
instances.explanation: כְּבוֹד יְהוָה (‘the glory of YHWH’) is an attribute term used metonymically and almost personified as it ‘enters’ the temple, representing YHWH’s own return.

deliberation: Examined רוּחַ (‘spirit’) to see if it is personified wind; within Ezekiel it usually denotes the Spirit of God as a real agent, so I treated it as literal in the visionary context. The statement that the house was ‘filled with the glory of YHWH’ again uses כָבוֹד in a metonymic/anthropomorphic way.

instances.english_text: lo, the Presence (glory) of GOD filled the temple
target: the actual indwelling of YHWH in the temple
ground: God’s presence is conceived as filling space like a tangible brightness or weight
attribute used for person/place occupancy
spatial imagery for presence
instances.explanation: The ‘glory of YHWH’ functions metonymically for YHWH’s presence and is described as ‘filling’ the house, a quasi‑physical and personifying way to depict divine indwelling.

deliberation: The verse simply states that a voice spoke from the house while a man stood beside Ezekiel. No non‑literal body‑part terms, no similes, no idioms beyond standard narrative reporting.

Noted several non‑literal expressions: the temple described as God’s throne/footstool (anthropomorphic metaphor), ‘defile my holy name’ (metonymy: name for reputation/being), and ‘their harlotry’ (metaphor for idolatry). Treated these as three distinct figurative instances.

instances.hebrew_text: אֶת־מְקוֹם כִּסְאִי וְאֶת־מְקוֹם כַּפּוֹת רַגְלַי אֲשֶׁר אֶשְׁכָּן־שָׁם
instances.english_text: this is the place of My throne and the place for the soles of My feet, where I will dwell
target: the temple as locus of God’s rule and presence
vehicle: throne and footstool of a king
ground: just as a throne and footstool mark where a king sits and places his feet, so the temple marks God’s ruling presence resting among Israel
spatial seat of authority
concept of sovereignty and nearness
instances.explanation: God uses royal and bodily imagery—throne and footstool—to metaphorically construe the temple as the place where his sovereign presence ‘sits’ and ‘rests’ among Israel.

instances.hebrew_text: לֹא יְטַמְּאוּ עוֹד בֵּית־יִשְׂרָאֵל שֵׁם קׇדְשִׁי
instances.english_text: The House of Israel ... must not again defile My holy name
ground: defiling the ‘name’ stands for disgracing God himself, since the name represents the person and reputation
part (name) for whole (person)
cultural association of name with honor
instances.explanation: God’s ‘holy name’ functions metonymically for God himself and his reputation; to defile the name is to bring dishonor upon God’s person.

ground: idolatry is like marital infidelity—betrayal of an exclusive covenant bond
unfaithfulness and illicit intimacy
social image of treachery
instances.explanation: The term ‘harlotry’ is a common prophetic metaphor for idolatry, casting Israel’s religious betrayal as sexual unfaithfulness to a covenant partner.

deliberation: Considered doorposts/thresholds as possibly symbolic; in context they refer concretely to royal or idolatrous buildings abutting the temple. The striking figurative element is ‘I consumed them in my anger’, with אכל used metaphorically for total destruction.

instances.english_text: and I consumed them in My anger
target: God’s act of judging the people/kings
ground: just as eating consumes and makes something disappear, so God’s wrath brings about complete destruction
thorough removal and overpowering force
intensity and finality of the act
instances.explanation: The verb ‘I consumed (ate) them’ is a metaphor, with some hyperbolic force, for God’s annihilating judgment; people are not literally eaten but utterly destroyed.

deliberation: Again, ‘harlotry’ is used metaphorically for idolatry. The command to ‘put it far from Me’ uses spatial language for relational/moral distance, but that is tightly bound to the harlotry metaphor; I focus on the main lexical metaphor.

ground: idolatry is conceptualized as sexual betrayal of a partner, implying intimacy, exclusivity, and treachery
unfaithfulness and pollution
social stigma of prostitution
posture: call to repentant separation from sin
instances.explanation: The term ‘harlotry’ again metaphorically labels idolatry as sexual infidelity toward God, the covenant partner, from whom such ‘harlotry’ must be put far away.

deliberation: The verse commands Ezekiel to describe the temple so the house of Israel can measure its plan and become ashamed of their iniquities. ‘Be ashamed’ is an emotional state, not figurative here; the rest is straightforward architectural language.

The verse catalogs features of the temple plan with no metaphorical body‑part terms (other than ordinary ‘entrances’ and ‘exits’), no similes, and no idioms beyond normal instructions. It is literal architectural/procedural description.

Describes the ‘instruction of the house’ and its boundaries as ‘most holy.’ ‘Most holy’ (קֹדֶשׁ קָדָשִׁים) is a technical cultic superlative, not figurative in context; it sets status, not a metaphorical mapping.

Dimensions are mainly literal. The phrase גַּב הַמִּזְבֵּחַ (‘back of the altar’) uses a body‑part term for a structural feature; that is a lexicalized metaphor mapping human/animal anatomy onto architecture.

instances.english_text: And this is the height/back of the altar
target: a particular structural part or height of the altar
ground: as a back is the rear/upright part of a body, so this section is the raised part of the altar
shape and positional similarity
using bodily terms to structure space
instances.explanation: The altar is described using the anatomical term ‘back’, a conventional metaphor that personifies the structure by borrowing human/animal body terminology.

deliberation: The key phrase מֵחֵיק הָאָרֶץ (‘from the bosom of the earth’) is an obvious metaphor/personification of the earth as having a chest or lap; the rest of the verse lists literal measurements.

instances.english_text: From the trench in the ground (lit. from the bosom of the earth)
target: the lowest recessed level of the altar in the ground
ground: as a bosom is an inner, enfolding part of a person, so the earth’s surface is pictured as an embracing recess that holds the altar’s base
interior enfolding and support
body‑based spatial schema
instances.explanation: The earth is personified as having a bosom or lap from which the altar rises, using bodily imagery to describe the base level in spatial terms.

deliberation: The term ‘horns’ (קְרָנוֹת) for the four projections of the altar is a standard architectural metaphor drawn from animal horns; it is first specified here. The rest is literal measurement.

target: the corner projections of the altar
ground: both are pointed projections extending from a main body, visually and functionally reminiscent of horns
shape and prominence
shared visual schema
instances.explanation: Calling the altar’s corner projections ‘horns’ is a conventional metaphor based on resemblance to animal horns.

deliberation: Specifies length, breadth, and squareness of the hearth (אֲרִיאֵל); no explicit figurative comparisons or body‑part terms beyond the already lexicalized name of the section. I treat it as architectural description.
Describes dimensions, border, trench, and the orientation of the steps. Terms like ‘border’ and ‘steps’ are literal; no metaphor, simile, or idiom appears here.

Introduces ‘these are the statutes of the altar’ and mentions offering burnt offerings and dashing blood. Within cultic law this is literal procedure; no special metaphorical language beyond standard ritual vocabulary.

Mentions priests ‘who are near to Me’ serving God. In temple idiom this nearness is spatially literal within the sanctuary; the rest describes a literal bull for a sin offering. I did not isolate a clear cross‑domain metaphor beyond standard cultic locutions.

The actions on the altar—‘thus you shall purge it and perform atonement for it’—treat the inanimate altar as bearing sin requiring purgation/atonement. This is a personifying metaphor mapping moral cleansing onto ritual procedures on an object.

instances.english_text: thus you shall purge it and perform purification upon it
ground: the altar is conceptualized as if it could bear impurity like a person and thus be ‘de‑sinned’ and atoned for
transfer of sin and cleansing to an object
shared notion of impurity removable by prescribed action
instances.explanation: Language normally used for morally culpable persons (‘purge, atone for’) is applied to the altar, personifying it and metaphorically construing ritual impurity as removable ‘sin’.

deliberation: Describes taking the bull of the sin offering and burning it in a designated area outside the sanctuary. All terminology is standard ritual instruction used literally.

As in v.20, the altar is said to be ‘purged’ (חִטְּאוּ אֶת־הַמִּזְבֵּחַ) by the offering, personifying it as if it carried sin. I treat this as a repeated but distinct occurrence of the same metaphor/personification in this verse.

instances.english_text: and the altar shall be purged [with it] just as it was purged with the bull
target: the altar’s impure state from prior use or presence of sin
ground: the altar is treated as if it can be ‘sinned’ and then ‘de‑sinned’ like a person, so ritual defilement is mapped onto a moral impurity schema
impurity as removable contamination
shared concept of cleansing through sacrifice
instances.explanation: The verb ‘to purge/de‑sin’ is applied to the altar, personifying it and employing the moral metaphor of sin as defilement removable through prescribed sacrifice.

deliberation: Speaks of completing the purging and then offering unblemished animals. The purging in this verse is a summary of the same concept already treated in v.20, but the wording here (‘when you have finished purging’) is procedural, with no additional figurative expression beyond that already captured in the earlier verse.
Instructs offering animals, putting salt on them, and offering as a burnt offering. These are literal ritual actions; no cross‑domain metaphor or special idiom appears.

Lists the daily sequence of offerings for seven days. The number seven has symbolic resonance elsewhere, but here it functions as an actual prescribed duration in a ritual; there is no explicit figurative language in the verse itself.

Again has the altar as the object of ‘atonement’ and ‘purification’ (personifying metaphor as in vv.20,22). Additionally, the idiom ‘fill its hand’ (וּמִלְאוּ יָדָו) is used for consecration—an established technical idiom in priestly texts.

instances.hebrew_text: שִׁבְעַת יָמִים יְכַפְּרוּ אֶת־הַמִּזְבֵּחַ וְטִהֲרוּ אֹתוֹ
instances.english_text: Seven days they shall purge the altar and purify it
vehicle: atoning and purifying a person from sin or uncleanness
ground: the altar is conceptualized as if it can be cleansed and atoned for like a person, again mapping sin/impurity onto an inanimate object
contamination removable by ritual process
shared ideas of purity and atonement
instances.explanation: The verbs ‘atone for’ and ‘purify’ are applied to the altar, personifying it and using moral cleansing language for a physical object.

instances.english_text: thus shall it be consecrated (lit. they will fill its hand)
target: the act of installing/consecrating the altar for service
ground: as a filled hand is equipped or supplied for a task, so the altar is fully equipped/authorized for its service
equipping/empowering through what is placed in the hand
gesture symbolizing authorization and readiness
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘fill the hand’ is used formulaically for consecration; it likely originated in the literal act of placing offerings in the priest’s hands but has become a technical expression for ordaining or dedicating, here applied to the altar.

deliberation: The phrase ‘I will accept you’ (וְרָצִיתִי אֶתְכֶם) expresses divine favor in terms of acceptance/pleasure; it builds on sacrificial ‘acceptability’ and extends it to the people themselves. This is a relational metaphor drawn from the cult of pleasing offerings.

instances.english_text: and I will extend My favor to you (lit. I will accept you)
target: God’s renewed relationship with the people
ground: as an acceptable offering meets the standard and is received with pleasure, so the people will be received into God’s favor
status of being pleasing/approved
from cultic acceptability to relational approval
instances.explanation: The verb רצה, often used of an acceptable sacrifice, is applied metonymically and metaphorically to the people themselves: they will be like an accepted offering, signifying God’s renewed favor.
